Award.AbstractNarration:
The proposed research concerns the use of ideas from mathematical logic to enhance the understanding of some central objects in mathematics: symmetries, functions, and differential equations. The part of mathematical logic which is relevant to the proposed research is model theory, which is about the ways in which mathematical objects or classes of objects are defined linguistically. Although mathematical logic has traditional connections with the philosophy and foundations of mathematics, there have been many recent applications to core areas of mathematics, and the proposed research is in the latter tradition. Among key problems to be studied are: (i) classifying the ways in which a "group" (collection of symmetries) can act as symmetries of a nice space, sometimes under some model theoretic assumptions, and (ii) what are the equations satisfied by some very special functions, such as exponential functions.

Here are some more details, written for mathematicians. The proposed research has two main parts. A central theme of the first part is the classification of groups definable in models of a first order theory without the independence property. This belongs to the "tame" model theory of groups, generalizing "stable group theory" which itself generalizes part of the theory of algebraic groups. Although the motivation belongs largely to "pure" model theory, this part of the proposal touches also on topological dynamics and Lie groups. For example we expect to produce "new" invariants of a discrete group, with many questions raised. The second part of the proposal deals with applications of model theory to diophantine geometry over function fields, building on earlier work of the PI and others. One problem is the extension of Ax-Schanuel-type theorems, on exponentiation and transcendence, to families of semiabelian varieties. Another problem is to obtain a "transparent" account of the positive characteristic Mordell-Lang conjecture (due originally to Hrushovski).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main outcomes of the project are (i) applying topological dynamics to logic, obtaining new descriptions of basic objects of model theory, and conversely applying notions of logic to dynamics obtaining new invariants of abstract and topological groups, (ii) classification of definable Lie groups with respect to the real and p-adic numbers, (iii)  Using methods from logic/model theory to obtain new results on symmetries and algebraic independence of solutions sets of differential equations, (iv) Giving a second generation proof of the function field Mordell-Lang conjecture, which was one of the major applications of logic to algebraic geometry and number theory.

Over the period of the project, the PI has advised several doctoral students: Joel Nagloo got his Ph.D. from Leeds, UK, in the summer of 2014, Ningyuan Yao got his Ph.D. from Sun-Yat-Sen University, China in the summer of 2015, and Somayeh Vojdani got her Ph.D. from Notre Dame in the summer of 2016.  The PI has also been advising the postdoctoral scholar Gabriel Conant at Notre Dame over the bulk of the period of the project. The PI has organized several conferences and workshops aimed at junior researchers.  The PI has also given some talks to fairly general audiences, such as in the Recognizing Excellence Series,  Waterloo, Canada, June 2018. 

Here are more details concerning some of the outcomes of the award.

Model theory is a branch of mathematical logic. In model theory we study first order theories. There are problems and questions internal to the subject. But the model-theoretic methods and results are often meaningful to other areas of mathematics, such as differential equations, geometry, group theory, number theory, when considering specific first order theories. The first part of the project concerns mainly problems and objects internal to model theory, such as connected components of definable groups, and Galois groups of first order theories.  One of the main contributions of the project, carried out by the PI in collaboration with  Krupinski,  was to apply ideas from the area of topological dynamics, in particular the "generalized Bohr compactification" from Eli Glasner's thesis to show that the Galois group of a first order theory is naturally the image a compact Hausdorff group. In more recent work, we deduce properties of a first order theory such as G-compactness, from "amenability" of the automorphism group of a suitable model. 

We now discuss applications to differential equations. The relevant first order theory is the theory of "differentially closed fields".  There is an established (Galois) theory of symmetriers of solutions of linear and related differential equations.  An important outcome of the project, carried out by the PI collaboration with Kamensky was to show the existence of Galois extensions of differential fields with prescribed properties, generalizing results by algebraic geometers but using methods of logic rather than algebraic geometry. 

Another successful aspect of the project was the culmination of around 15 years of work by the PI around trying to find an accessible and black-box free account of one of the major contributions of logic to geometry and number theory, namely Hrushovski's proof of so-called function field Mordell-Lang in positive characteristic. In collaboration with Benoist and Bouscaren, the PI was able to find a desiredaccessible proof by reducing the Mordell-Lang conjecture to a special case, the Manin-Mumford conjecture.
